conclusion: To solve this problem, we need to analyze the forces acting on the system and use the principles of static equilibrium.
OA and OB are two fixed optical slide rods in the vertical plane, and the angle between OA vertical, OB and OA is 45°.
The two rods are covered with light rings E and F that can move freely, and an object with mass m is suspended at the node D point by a non-extendable light rope.
When the object is at rest, the force between ring E and rod OA is F1, and the force between ring F and rod OB is F2.
Weight of the object (mg) acts downward from point D.
Tension in the rope (T) acts along the rope from D to E and from D to F.
Normal forces (F1 and F2) act perpendicular to the rods OA and OB at points E and F, respectively.

premise: Since the system is in static equilibrium, the sum of forces in any direction must be zero.
conclusion: The tension in the rope (T) can be resolved into components along OA and perpendicular to OA for Ring E.

premise: The tension in the rope (T) can be resolved into components along OA and perpendicular to OA.
conclusion: The component of T along OA is T cos(45°).

premise: The tension in the rope (T) can be resolved into components along OA and perpendicular to OA.
conclusion: The component of T perpendicular to OA is T sin(45°).

premise: The tension in the rope (T) can be resolved into components along OB and perpendicular to OB for Ring F.
conclusion: The component of T along OB is T cos(45°).

premise: The tension in the rope (T) can be resolved into components along OB and perpendicular to OB.
conclusion: The component of T perpendicular to OB is T sin(45°).

premise: Vertical Equilibrium: The sum of the vertical components of the forces must equal the weight of the object.
Horizontal Equilibrium: The sum of the horizontal components of the forces must be zero.
